As well as following the title of this dissertation project: The Interplay of Video Games and Human Psychology: An Insight into Motivations, Effects, and Therapeutic Potentials
Can you write 200 words for ethical considerations?

Ethical Considerations

The interplay between video games and human psychology encompasses several ethical considerations crucial to our investigation. First, respecting participant privacy and confidentiality is paramount, especially when dealing with sensitive psychological outcomes. Data collected for this study, particularly concerning individual motivations, effects on mental health, and therapeutic potentials, will be anonymized to protect identities. Furthermore, the issue of informed consent is critical; all participants must be fully aware of the study's scope, including potential risks and benefits, and their consent must be explicitly obtained and documented.

Another key ethical concern relates to the psychological wellbeing of participants. Engaging with video games, especially those designed to manipulate emotions or induce stress for therapeutic purposes, could potentially harm individuals. We commit to closely monitoring participants' psychological states and providing support mechanisms for those adversely affected.

Moreover, the depiction and inclusion of certain video games may involve sensitive content, raising concerns over exposure to violence or triggering themes. We will carefully select games to minimize harm, ensuring they are culturally and developmentally appropriate for our participant group.

Finally, there's an ethical obligation to critically examine and report any biases or limitations in our study. It involves acknowledging the complex nature of psychological responses to video games and avoiding overgeneralization of findings. Through a thorough ethical review and adherence to ethical guidelines, this study aims to contribute responsibly and meaningfully to the understanding of video games' psychological impacts.

A system can be defined as an arrangement consisting of physical components that
are connected or related in such a way that they act as an entire unit (DiStefano et al
2011). Kump et al (2011) defines a system as an entity that is composed of diverse
parts (components) that are inter-related. Together they function as a complex
whole. A system may also exhibit adaptive, dynamic and evolutionary behaviour
(Meadows, 2008). DiStefano et al (2011) go on to define a control system as being
an arrangement of physical components that are connected in such a manner as to
regulate itself or another system. Given this definition, it could be argued that the
physical environment is abound with control systems.
A systems approach can be applied in virtually any area of inquiry (Kump et al 2011).
By studying the environment in systems terms and gaining an insight into its
behaviour at a particular moment in time, it might be possible to build a more
accurate picture of both the past behaviour of a physical system, whilst making more
accurate predictions about the future. This can be especially important, for example,
when considering the extent to which anthropogenic activity is responsible for
modifications of the environment and the consequences of such change.
Components of a system inter-relate in such a way as to determine the state of the
system by allowing for the flow of information from one component to the next via
links known as couplings. (Kump et al, 2011) Both positive and negative couplings
can exist. In the case of a positive coupling, a change in one component, leads to a
change in the same direction in the connected component, e.g. an increase in
insolation could directly result in an increase in the Earth’s surface temperature.
Conversely, in a negative coupling, a change in one component would result in a
change in the opposite direction in the connected component, e.g. an increase in
surface albedo would directly result in a reduction of the Earth’s surface temperature
(Kump et al 2011).

Figure 3.1.1. An example of a negative coupling (A), where an increase in albedo
results in a reduction in surface temperature and a positive coupling (B), where an
increase in insolation results in an increase in surface temperature.
Couplings may also result in a feedback loop, which is defined by Kump et al (2011
p.22) as a “self perpetuating mechanism of change and response to that change”.
Feedback loops may also be negative or positive, where negative loops reduce the
effects of the disturbance and where positive loops amplify the effects. Figure 3.1.2
shows an example of a positive feedback loop where an increase in albedo results in
a reduction in surface temperature. In turn, this increases ice-cover, which also has
the effect of increasing the albedo.
Figure 3.1.2. An example of a positive feedback loop, where an increase in albedo
results in a reduction in surface temperature, allowing ice cover to increase which, in
turn, further increases albedo.
A system is described as being in a state of equilibrium when it does not change until
something creates a disturbance. Equilibrium may be either stable or unstable. In a
stable state of equilibrium, a small disturbance to the system will result in responses
(A)
(B)
S810 MSc Project: H2O and CO2 as a forcing mechanism on the Noachian Climate System
19
that will quickly return the system to a state of equilibrium. In a system in an
unstable state of equilibrium, however, a small disturbance may result in system
adjustments that carry the system further and further from its original state until a
new state of equilibrium, if such a state exists.
Looking, then, in a system with a single feedback loop, a negative loop demonstrates
a state of stable equilibrium whilst a positive feedback loop demonstrates a state of
unstable equilibrium. In the case of environmental and natural systems, such as the
Mars climate system, however, the reality is considerably more complex. Systems
such as these are typically made up of a combination of several subsystems that
may consist of both positive and negative feedback loops (Meadows, 2008).
A perturbation of a system is a temporary disturbance of a system, whereas a forcing
mechanism is a more persistent disturbance. Kump et al (2011) gives as an
example of a perturbation, the volcanic outgassing of sulphur dioxide into the
atmosphere during a terrestrial (Earth) eruption. As the SO2 reacts to form sulphate
aerosols in the atmosphere in the weeks following the eruption, it prevents a small
amount of insolation reaching the Earth’s surface, lowering average global
temperatures. The eruption of Mount Pinatubo in June1991 (Watanabe et al, 2004)
was an example of this, where temperatures a lowering of average global
temperatures by 0.3-0.5 °C for 2-4 years (Robock et al, 1991) was attributed to the
eruption. Over the course of some years (some Pinatubo aerosols were found to
decay as recently as the late 1990s (Watanabe et al, 2004)), however, temperatures
returned to previous levels as the sulphur was naturally removed from the
atmosphere. As Kump et al (2011) states, it is difficult, however, to definitively
attribute such variation to the eruption alone, as the climate is naturally variable.
Forcing mechanisms, on the other hand, such as increasing levels of sunlight
received by the Earth over billions of years, are more persistent in nature. This
project focuses on volcanic outgassing of carbon dioxide and water as a forcing
mechanism on the Mars climate system during the Noachian because volcanism is
considered in a more sustained fashion, rather than an isolated eruption, which, in
itself, may have a very temporary effect on the Martian climate, in terms of geological
timescales. For the purposes of this project, a period of extensive and repeated
volcanism is considered as the principal forcing mechanism responsible for shifting

the climate system into a state of equilibrium capable of supporting liquid water at
the surface.
